definition: Sun Wu, also known as Sun Tzu 孫子|孙子[Sun1 zi3] (c. 500 BC, dates of birth and death uncertain), general, strategist and philosopher of the Spring and Autumn Period (700-475 BC), believed to be the author of the “Art of War” 孫子兵法|孙子兵法[Sun1 zi3 Bing1 fa3], one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1]
grandson/descendant
surname Sun
surname Wu
martial/military

Sun Wu, famous general, strategist and Legalist philosopher, contemporary with Confucius 孔子[Kong3 zi3] (551-479 BC), author of "The Art of War" 孫子兵法|孙子兵法[Sun1 zi3 Bing1 fa3]/also known as Sun Tzu 孫子|孙子[Sun1 zi3]

sentences.english: In spite of this, Sun Wu explained to them in great detail how to march in the four directions.
sentences.chinese: 但是，孙武还是把这些详详细细地向她们解释了一遍。

sentences.english: Then the king called in one hundred and eighty maids of honor and ordered Sun Wu to train them.
sentences.chinese: 于是吴王召来一百八十名宫女，命令孙武来训练她们。

sentences.english: He later introduced Changsha's rich tourism resources to Sun Wu.
sentences.chinese: 张剑飞向孙武介绍了长沙的一系列旅游资源。

sentences.english: Sun Wu organized the young ladies into two teams and appointed two of the king's favorite concubines team leaders.
sentences.chinese: 孙武将宫女分为两队，叫吴王的两个宠姬担任队长。

sentences.english: In this limited space, Sun Wu expounds his wide-ranging views on war.
sentences.chinese: 在这不长的篇幅中，孙武全面论述了对战争的看法。

definition: Zou Yan (305-240 BC), founder of the School of Yin-Yang of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
Han Fei, also known as Han Feizi 韓非子|韩非子[Han2 Fei1 zi3] (c. 280-233 BC), Legalist philosopher of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)

Sun Wu, famous general, strategist and Legalist philosopher, contemporary with Confucius 孔子[Kong3 zi3] (551-479 BC), author of "The Art of War" 孫子兵法|孙子兵法[Sun1 zi3 Bing1 fa3]/also known as Sun Tzu 孫子|孙子[Sun1 zi3]
Liu Yu, founder of Song of the Southern dynasties 劉宋|刘宋[Liu2 Song4], broke away from Eastern Jin in 420, reigned as Emperor Wu of Song 宋武帝[Song4 Wu3 di4]
art of war/military strategy and tactics
Zhaoge, capital of the Shang dynasty 商朝/Zhaoge town in Qi county 淇縣|淇县, Hebi 鶴壁|鹤壁, Henan
Su Qin (340-284 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
the School of the Military, one of the Hundred Schools of Thought 諸子百家|诸子百家[zhu1 zi3 bai3 jia1] of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
military strategist in ancient China/military commander/soldier
imperial strategic adviser/expert on strategy

Li Jing (570-649 AD), Tang Dynasty general and purported author of "Duke Li of Wei Answering Emperor Taizong of Tang" 唐太宗李衛公問對|唐太宗李卫公问对[Tang2 Tai4 zong1 Li3 Wei4 Gong1 Wen4 dui4], one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1]
to brag/popular/lovely
Gongsun Long (c. 325-250 BC), leading thinker of the School of Logicians of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Lu Su or Lu Zijing 魯子敬|鲁子敬 (172-217), statesman, diplomat and strategist of Eastern Wu 東吳|东吴
Wu Zixu (-484 BC), powerful politician in Wu/famous as destitute refugee begging in Wu town, cf 吳市吹簫|吴市吹箫
a book on the art of war
skilled manipulator/tactician/strategist/advisor/counsellor
